pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [5c5f46d4d5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17189/commits/5c5f46d4d58d100e6f2bb021ac0d2163736d9d09)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ getElem_def`
`+ getElem_map`
`+ getElem_pmap`
`+ head_pmap`
`+ map_pmap`
`+ pmap`
`+ pmap_cons`
`+ pmap_cons'`
`+ pmap_map`
`+ pmap_nil`
`+ tail_pmap`
`+ toList_getElem`
`+ toList_pmap`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

We looked at this during the review triage party, and the code looks fine, but we are wondering about the motivation for adding more API to mathlib vectors, since they aren't used very much in the library and batteries vectors will probably replace them eventually. Can you comment on why you are using the `Vector` type rather than alternatives such as `List`, functions out of `Fin n`, etc?

> We looked at this during the review triage party, and the code looks fine, but we are wondering about the motivation for adding more API to mathlib vectors, since they aren't used very much in the library and batteries vectors will probably replace them eventually. Can you comment on why you are using the `Vector` type rather than alternatives such as `List`, functions out of `Fin n`, etc?

I use it in #17145 . I'm using it instead of `List` because the statement specifically uses vectors of length 31, and they are used a lot. I'm not using functions out of `Fin n` because the operations I'm using feel more list-like then function-like, although that's just intuition, and I also have some vague hope that eventually it could run against the official grader to give a verified executable solution (and functions from `Fin n` would be inefficient there)
That's a very good reason, I'm happy with that. I vote we maintainer-merge this one â€“Â Yael, is that ok with you?
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11654009478/job/32447026087)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11654009478/job/32447025910)

Yep, motivation is here and code is good!

maintainer merge

Yep, motivation is here and code is good!

maintainer merge
Can you write a version of this lemma backwards deriving `âˆ€ x âˆˆ (cons a v).toList, p x` from `âˆ€ x âˆˆ v.toList, p x` and `p a`, rather than the other way around?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Vector): add `pmap` for vectors and prove some lemmas

source.title: feat(Archive/Ioi/Ioi2024Q2): a proof of the solution of question 2 from IOI 2024.

We looked at this during the review triage party, and the code looks fine, but we are wondering about the motivation for adding more API to mathlib vectors, since they aren't used very much in the library and batteries vectors will probably replace them eventually. Can you comment on why you are using the `Vector` type rather than alternatives such as `List`, functions out of `Fin n`, etc?

> We looked at this during the review triage party, and the code looks fine, but we are wondering about the motivation for adding more API to mathlib vectors, since they aren't used very much in the library and batteries vectors will probably replace them eventually. Can you comment on why you are using the `Vector` type rather than alternatives such as `List`, functions out of `Fin n`, etc?

I use it in #17145 . I'm using it instead of `List` because the statement specifically uses vectors of length 31, and they are used a lot. I'm not using functions out of `Fin n` because the operations I'm using feel more list-like then function-like, although that's just intuition, and I also have some vague hope that eventually it could run against the official grader to give a verified executable solution (and functions from `Fin n` would be inefficient there)
That's a very good reason, I'm happy with that. I vote we maintainer-merge this one â€“Â Yael, is that ok with you?

Yep, motivation is here and code is good!
